Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaborative Research on the Role of Singlet Molecular Oxygen in Urban Atmospheres Rich In Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program, Professors Krishna Foster and Matthias Selke of California State University, Los Angeles are investigating the impact of urban particulate matter on the lower atmosphere of Earth. The project is performed in collaboration with Professor Donald Dabdub of the University of California at Irvine. Urban particulate matter contains polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) generated from incomplete combustion processes, including motor vehicles fueled by gasoline and diesel. Although some PAHs are known to transfer energy to oxygen forming more reactive molecules, it is hard to know which PAHs are responsible for this energy transfer and how many times this occurs in the environment. The scope and accuracy of these energy transfer measurements is being improved with this project. Success in this research may improve air quality models and that are used to understand the impact of pollution on people, especially those living in urban areas. The students assisting in this research reflect the diverse population of southern California. Consequently, this project has the potential to increase the number of underserved students that select careers in the chemical sciences and pursue graduate education, addressing the nation's need for students preparing for chemical sciences careers.

The investigators work to identify PAH and oxygenated-PAH that are net sources of singlet molecular oxygen in solution by measuring singlet oxygen quantum yields and quenching rates. Alkene oxidation products formed from reactions with singlet molecular oxygen are characterized using multiple analytical techniques. Both laboratory experiments and air quality models are used to determine the potential role of PAH photoexcitation on oxidation in emission plumes and at the air/particle interface.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nearly 50 years ago, the potential role of singlet molecular oxygen (O2(1Δg)) as an oxidant in the lower atmosphere was heavily debated.  However, advancements in atmospheric kinetics showed the gaseous reaction rates of hydroxyl radical with volatile organic compounds were much faster than those with O2(1Δg), and research on atmospheric O2(1Δg) lessened. Faster rate constants or additional sources of O2(1Δg) would increase the significance of O2(1Δg) chemistry in the lower atmosphere.   This project shows that O2 (1Δg) is produced when a solvated polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH e.g., pyrene) ubiquitous in urban atmospheres, is irradiated in the presence of oxygen.

 

The work is a collaboration between experimental and computational atmospheric scientists.  The experimental part of the work was performed at Cal State LA under the leadership of Prof. Krishna Foster.  Luminescence decay techniques were used to measure the quantum yield of O2(1Δg) production as 0.78 +/- 0.08 and found that quenching of O2(1Δg) by pyrene is rather insignificant with a  rate constant of only  1.4 x 104 M-1 s-1.  Irradiating toluene-d8 solutions of pyrene and 2,3-dimethyl-2-butene leads to rapid formation of the corresponding allylic hydroperoxide consistent with oxidation by O2 (1Δg).

 

The computational part of the work was performed at UC Irvine under the leadership of Prof. Donald Dabdub.  The main goal of this work is to reexamine the role of O2 (1Δg) chemistry on the lower atmosphere.   Revisiting the role of O2 (1Δg) oxidation in polluted urban atmospheres is especially interesting because these systems contain high concentrations of organic compounds, including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), which are products of incomplete combustion processes.  Automobiles and trucks powered by petroleum-based fuels are well-known sources of PAH in urban atmospheres. 

 

 The UCI-CIT air quality model was used to assess the potential role of O2 (1Δg) formed by photo-excitation of PAH in a polluted urban environment. The model domain is divided horizontally into an 80 x 30 grid of 5 x 5 km cells, and vertically into five layers covering 1100 m above the surface. The domain covers the entire South Coast air basin of California (SoCAB) region including Orange County, and parts of Los Angeles, Ventura, San Bernardino and Riverside counties. Computational simulations of the atmosphere were developed which incorporate the experimental findings develope at Cal State LA.  Results indicate that  if other polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons yield O2 (1Δg) as does pyrene, this chemistry may impact the formation of secondary organic aerosol.


Last Modified: 11/20/2019
Modified by: Donald Dabdub

Image
  • Predicted 24-hour average SOA concentrations in the base UCI-CIT model (left panel), and change to predicted 24-hour average SOA concentrations after adding O2 (1Δg) related chemistry, assuming all PAHs form O2 (1Δg), and removing O2 (1Δg) quenching reactions (right panel).
    Donald Dabdub
    Copyrighted
    Donald Dabdub
    Secondary Organic Aerosol
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Nearly 50 years ago, the potential role of singlet molecular oxygen (O2(1Δg)) as an oxidant in the lower atmosphere was heavily debated. However, advancements in atmospheric kinetics showed the gaseous reaction rates of hydroxyl radical with volatile organic compounds were much faster than those with O2(1Δg), and research on atmospheric O2(1Δg) lessened. Faster rate constants or additional sources of O2(1Δg) would increase the significance of O2(1Δg) chemistry in the lower atmosphere. This project shows that O2 (1Δg) is produced when a solvated polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH e.g., pyrene) ubiquitous in urban atmospheres, is irradiated in the presence of oxygen. The work is a collaboration between experimental and computational atmospheric scientists. The experimental part of the work was performed at Cal State LA under the leadership of Prof. Krishna Foster. Luminescence decay techniques were used to measure the quantum yield of O2(1Δg) production as 0.78 +/- 0.08 and found that quenching of O2(1Δg) by pyrene is rather insignificant with a rate constant of only 1.4 x 104 M-1 s-1. Irradiating toluene-d8 solutions of pyrene and 2,3-dimethyl-2-butene leads to rapid formation of the corresponding allylic hydroperoxide consistent with oxidation by O2 (1Δg). The computational part of the work was performed at UC Irvine under the leadership of Prof. Donald Dabdub. The main goal of this work is to reexamine the role of O2 (1Δg) chemistry on the lower atmosphere. Revisiting the role of O2 (1Δg) oxidation in polluted urban atmospheres is especially interesting because these systems contain high concentrations of organic compounds, including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), which are products of incomplete combustion processes. Automobiles and trucks powered by petroleum-based fuels are well-known sources of PAH in urban atmospheres. The UCI-CIT air quality model was used to assess the potential role of O2 (1Δg) formed by photo-excitation of PAH in a polluted urban environment. The model domain is divided horizontally into an 80 x 30 grid of 5 x 5 km cells, and vertically into five layers covering 1100 m above the surface. The domain covers the entire South Coast air basin of California (SoCAB) region including Orange County, and parts of Los Angeles, Ventura, San Bernardino and Riverside counties. Computational simulations of the atmosphere were developed which incorporate the experimental findings develope at Cal State LA. Results indicate that if other polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons yield O2 (1Δg) as does pyrene, this chemistry may impact the formation of secondary organic aerosol.
